bestBHT.bht: In her distress, the woman kept saying to herself, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole. Her remarkable faith propelled her to seek contact with the glorious Healer. Timid and shy, she quietly pressed through the crowd and touched the hem of his garment, believing that this simple act would bring about her healing. This encounter is also mentioned in the accounts of Matthew and Luke.

Henry Alford: For she said (was saying) perhaps need not be pressed to mean that she actually said it to someone - in herself may be understood.
At the same time, the imperfect looks very like the minute accuracy of one reporting what had been an habitual saying of the poor woman in her distress.
The poor woman in her distress.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole—that is, if I may but come in contact with this glorious Healer at all."
If I may but come in contact with this glorious Healer at all.
Marvin Vincent: For she said [ελεγεν] . Imperfect tense. She was or kept saying as she pressed through the crowd, either to herself or to others.
Philip Schaff: Matthew: 'within herself,' but it is possible that she may have murmured it again and again as she tried to get through the crowd.
Archibald T. Robertson: She was timid and shy from her disease and did not wish to attract attention.
So she crept up in the crowd and touched the hem or border of his garment.
John Gill: For she said,.... Within herself, such were her thoughts, and so great her faith:
if I may touch but his clothes I shall be whole;

bhtAttempts.bht: The woman in this verse, in the midst of her distress, was constantly saying to herself and possibly others, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole. Her faith in the Healer was remarkable, and she believed that coming into contact with him would bring her healing. She was timid and shy, not wanting to attract attention, so she crept through the crowd and touched the hem of his garment. Her thoughts and great faith led her to believe that this simple act would bring about her wholeness. According to other accounts of this event, Matthew and Luke also mention this encounter.

In her distress, the woman kept saying to herself, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole. Her remarkable faith propelled her to seek contact with the glorious Healer. Timid and shy, she quietly pressed through the crowd and touched the hem of his garment, believing that this simple act would bring about her healing. This encounter is also mentioned in the accounts of Matthew and Luke.

The poor woman, in the midst of her distress, continually said to herself, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole. Her faith was remarkable, as she believed that mere contact with the glorious Healer would bring about her healing. Timid and shy, she discreetly made her way through the crowd to touch the hem of his garment. This encounter is also detailed in the narratives of Matthew and Luke.

In Mark 5:28, the distressed woman expressed her hopeful belief by constantly saying to herself, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole. Her faith was truly remarkable, as she believed that even a simple touch would suffice to experience the healing power of the glorious Healer. Overwhelmed by her condition, she quietly maneuvered through the crowd, aiming to make contact with the hem of his garment, and in doing so, she demonstrated her unwavering trust in the miraculous healing that could manifest through this encounter.

The woman, in the midst of her distress, kept saying to herself, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole. Her remarkable faith in the glorious Healer led her to believe that a simple touch could bring about her healing. Overcoming her timidity, she discreetly pressed through the crowd to touch the hem of his garment. This encounter is also mentioned in other accounts.
